Generalized Boxplot

Source: R/generalized_boxplot.R
generalized_boxplot.Rd

This function computes the Generalized Boxplot, a robust data visualization technique for detecting outliers and skewness in a distribution, as proposed by Bruffaerts et al. (2014). It uses the Tukey g-and-h distribution (from the package TukeyGH77) to model the data.

Usage

generalized_boxplot(x, alpha = 0.95, gamma = 0.5)

Arguments

x

A numeric vector containing the data.

alpha

A numeric value between 0 and 1 specifying the desired coverage rate. Default is 0.95.

gamma

gamma to be defined

Value

A list containing the following components:

lower.fence

The lower fence value.

lower.quartile

The lower quartile value.

median

The median value.

upper.quartile

The upper quartile value.

upper.fence

The upper fence value.

lower.outliers

A vector containing the lower outliers.

upper.outliers

A vector containing the upper outliers.

References

Hubert, M., and Vandervieren, E. (2008). An adjusted boxplot for skewed distributions. Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 52(12):5186-5201.

Bruffaerts, C., Verardi, V., Vermandele, C. (2014). A generalized boxplot for skewed and heavy-tailed distributions. Statistics and Probability Letters 95(C):110–117

Author

Christian L. Goueguel

Examples

# Compute the Generalized Boxplot for a normal distribution
x <- rnorm(100)
gb <- generalized_boxplot(x)
print(gb)
#> $lower.fence
#> [1] 0.2073812
#> 
#> $lower.quartile
#> [1] -0.3043328
#> 
#> $median
#> [1] 0.213958
#> 
#> $upper.quartile

#>

# Compute the Generalized Boxplot for a skewed distribution
x <- rexp(100)
gb <- generalized_boxplot(x)
print(gb)
#> $lower.fence
#> [1] 0.624786
#> 
#> $lower.quartile
#> [1] 0.2687795
